wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant-General Sir Oswald Cuthbert Borrett,  (4 March 1878 –  28 July 1950) was a British Army officer who served as Commander of British Troops in China and Lieutenant of the Tower of London.

response: By Autumn 1941 the Directorate of Prisoners of War at the War Office had "all the trappings of a major bureaucratic machine". However all the leading members of the Directorate including Coates, his superior Sir Alan Hunter, Inspector Sir Oswald Borrett and Capt W. Rosser James were removed in September 1941.Compare the Army List for September 1941 with that for October 1941, on p. 16. General Sir Alan Hunter was succeeded by Major-General E.C. Gepp as Director of Prisoners of War."Director Of Prisoners Of War", The Times, 20 September 1941, p. 4. On 20 April 1942, having been convicted of a criminal offence, Coates was removed from the Army. Coates' entries in Who's Who and Kelly's Handbook to the Titled, Landed and Official Classes ceased at or shortly after this timeCoates is last to be found in Who's Who in 1942 (p. 605); his entry in Kelly's Handbook was continued until 1945 (p. 460). and his date of death is not recorded."Members since 1979", House of Commons Library Research Paper 09/31, p. 178.
